properties.description: Beginning of the American Revolution as an ideological and political movement.
Start of the American Revolutionary War.
Battles of Lexington and Concord.
Second Continental Congress convened in Philadelphia.
Continental Army formed by the Second Continental Congress.
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.
Declaration of Independence unanimously adopted by the Second Continental Congress.
Decisive victory by Washington and Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown.
Treaty of Paris signed, codifying US independence.
Establishment of the sovereign United States of America.
End of the French and Indian War.
British Parliament imposed new taxes on colonies to compensate for wartime costs.
Control of colonies' western lands turned over to British officials in Montreal.
Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress.
Stamp Act Congress drew up a Declaration of Rights and Grievances.
British Parliament's passage of the Townshend Acts.
King George III deployed British troops to Boston in an effort to quell rebellion.
British troops killed protesters in the Boston Massacre.
Anti-tax demonstrators destroyed the Royal Navy customs schooner Gaspee.
Sons of Liberty activists dumped chests of tea into Boston Harbor.
London responded to the Boston Tea Party by closing Boston Harbor.
London enacted a series of punitive laws (Intolerable Acts) effectively ending self-government in Massachusetts.
12 of the Thirteen Colonies sent delegates to the First Continental Congress.
First Continental Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance through underground networks of committees.
Following Lexington and Concord, Washington and the Continental Army responded by surrounding Boston.
Forcing the British to withdraw from Boston by sea.
Leaving Patriots in control in every colony.
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion.
Second Continental Congress began debating and deliberating on the Articles of Confederation.
Second Continental Congress passed the Lee Resolution, affirming support for national independence.
France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause of independence.
Roughly 7,500 British troops led by Charles Cornwallis captured during the Siege of Yorktown.
Siege of Yorktown leading to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament.
Consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms.
British signed the Treaty of Paris, granting former colonies territory east of the Mississippi River.
About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories.
English Civil War (1642–1651) and its aftermath.
Stuart Restoration of 1660.
Massachusetts did not recognize Charles II as king for over a year after his coronation.
King Philip's War (1675–1678), fought by New England colonies without English military assistance.
Charles II and James II attempted to bring New England under direct English control.
Crown nullified colonial charters in response to opposition to direct control.
James II consolidated New England colonies, New York, and New Jersey into the Dominion of New England.
James II tried to rule without Parliament.
English aristocracy removed James II from power in the Glorious Revolution of 1688.
The 1689 Boston revolt, which overthrew Dominion rule.
Colonial governments reasserted their control after the 1689 revolt.
William and Mary granted new charters to the individual New England colonies.
Parliament passed the first in a series of Navigation Acts, restricting colonial trade.
The Molasses Act 1733 placed a duty of six pence per gallon upon foreign molasses.
The Molasses Act increased the smuggling of foreign molasses.
The British government ceased enforcement efforts of the Molasses Act after the 1740s.
Migration beyond the Appalachian Mountains increased after the French threat was removed.
Native Americans launched Pontiac's War (1763–1766) in response to increased migration.
The Grenville ministry issued the Royal Proclamation of 1763, designating western territory as an Indian Reserve.
The Royal Proclamation failed to stop westward migration.
Parliament passed the Sugar Act, decreasing duties but increasing enforcement.
Grenville proposed direct taxes on the colonies to raise revenue.
Parliament passed the Stamp Act, imposing direct taxes for the first time.
Shortly following adoption of the Stamp Act, the Sons of Liberty formed.
Sons of Liberty used public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence.
Several legislatures called for united action.
Stamp Act Congress organized a boycott on imports of all British merchandise.
The Rockingham government came to power in July 1765.
Parliament debated whether to repeal the stamp tax or enforce it.
Benjamin Franklin appeared before Parliament to make the case for repeal.
Parliament agreed and repealed the Stamp Act.
Parliament insisted in the Declaratory Act of March 1766 that they retained full power to make laws for the colonies.
Widespread celebrations in the colonies following the repeal of the Stamp Act.
Colonists responded to the Townshend Acts taxes by organizing new boycotts of British goods.
The Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter to the other colonies urging coordination.
The governor dissolved the Massachusetts Assembly when it refused to rescind the circular letter.
A riot broke out in Boston over the seizure of the sloop Liberty.
Customs officials were forced to flee Boston after the Sloop Liberty riot.
A Boston town meeting declared that no obedience was due to parliamentary laws.
A convention assembled but only issued a mild protest before dissolving itself.
Parliament responded to unrest by reactivating the Treason Act 1543.
A new ministry under Lord North came to power in 1770.
Parliament repealed most of the Townshend duties, except the tax on tea.
The repeal of most Townshend duties temporarily resolved the crisis.
The boycott of British goods largely ceased following the repeal of duties.
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence.
Virginia set up its Committee of Correspondence in early 1773.
Parliament passed the Tea Act lowering the price of taxed tea exported to the colonies.
The British government responded to the Boston Tea Party by passing four laws (Intolerable Acts).
Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves.
Massachusetts patriots formed an alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress.
The Provincial Congress began training militia outside British-occupied Boston.
The First Continental Congress called for a boycott of all British goods.
New local committees authorized by the Congress enforced the boycott.
British policy of salutary neglect, leaving colonies mostly alone.
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs.
National debt had grown substantially after the French and Indian War (£133 million).
The need for money played a part in important British decisions regarding colonies.
Colonial belief in and claiming of the unwritten British constitution and rights of Englishmen.
American spokesmen propounded 'republicanism' as best suited to American conditions.
Parliament at Westminster saw itself as the supreme lawmaking authority throughout the Empire.
Parliament argued the colonies were legally British corporations subordinate to the British Parliament.
Radical Whig ideology profoundly influenced American political philosophy with its love of liberty and opposition to tyrannical government.
British government pursued a policy of mercantilism.
The British government lacked the resources and information needed to control the colonies.
Stationing a standing army in Great Britain during peacetime was politically unacceptable.
Need for defense against Native Americans and foreign populations in newly acquired territories.
Desire to prevent white colonists from instigating conflict with Native Americans.
Desire to help collect customs duties.
Americans only paid 1 shilling in taxes to the empire compared to 26 shillings paid by the English.
The goods taxed by the Townshend Acts were widely used, making boycotts less effective.
Perception that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
Letters' contents used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights.
Rejection of monarchy and aristocracy as political philosophies.
British policy shift from salutary neglect to active intervention triggering colonial desire for greater autonomy.
Conflict arising from British attempts to impose taxes without colonial representation, violating perceived rights, leading to resistance.
British punitive responses to colonial actions (e.g., Tea Party -> Intolerable Acts) intensifying colonial unity and revolutionary cause.
Establishment and use of Committees of Correspondence to link patriots, coordinate resistance, and provide framework for rebel government.
Use of boycotts and protests against British goods/policies to exert economic and political pressure.
Military engagements (Lexington/Concord, Boston Siege, Yorktown) leading to shifts in territorial control and influencing British political will.
Events like English Civil War aftermath, King Philip's War, and resistance to direct control contributing to the development of a unique American identity separate from British.
The change in British policy after the French and Indian War, specifically regarding taxation and control, was the primary driver for the Thirteen Colonies seeking greater autonomy.
The belief that 'taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen' was the core ideological cause driving colonial resistance and the revolution.
The Committees of Correspondence effectively created an inter-colonial network essential for coordinating resistance and forming a rebel government framework.
British punitive measures like the Intolerable Acts, intended to quell rebellion, instead expanded and intensified the revolutionary cause across the colonies.
The decisive victory at the Siege of Yorktown directly led to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament and consensus to end the war on American terms.
Statement from the Stamp Act Congress's Declaration of Rights and Grievances.
Examples of actions taken by the Sons of Liberty (burning records, looting, Boston Tea Party).
British Parliament repealed the Stamp Act.
Content of the Declaratory Act asserting Parliament's supreme authority.
Argument from John Dickinson's Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania against the constitutionality of Townshend Acts taxes for revenue.
The circular letter issued by the Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony.
The event known as the Boston Massacre.
The burning of the HMS Gaspee in the Gaspee Affair.
Content of the private letters from Governor Hutchinson and Lt. Governor Oliver.
Benjamin Franklin acknowledging leaking letters and being removed from his position.
Establishment of Committees of Correspondence by Samuel Adams and spread to other colonies like Virginia.
Local committees enforcing the boycott called for by the First Continental Congress.
Demonstrators warning merchants, consignees forced to resign or tea turned back in most colonies.
Activists dumping tea into Boston Harbor in the Boston Tea Party.
Details of the four laws passed as the Intolerable Acts (Mass Govt Act, Admin Justice Act, Boston Port Act, Quartering Act).
Issuance of Suffolk Resolves and formation of the Provincial Congress in Massachusetts.
Provincial Congress beginning training of militia.
Actions of the First Continental Congress, including calling for a boycott.
The Battles of Lexington and Concord.
The Continental Army surrounding Boston and forcing British withdrawal.
Patriots gaining control in every colony after the British withdrawal from Boston.
King George III proclaiming Massachusetts in a state of open defiance and rebellion.
Passage of the Lee Resolution affirming support for national independence.
Unanimous adoption of the Declaration of Independence.
France entering the war to support the colonial cause.
Outcome of the Siege of Yorktown, including the capture of British troops.
Signing of the Treaty of Paris in 1783.

properties.name: Colonial Separatist Leaders
properties.beliefs: Initially sought autonomy, came to embrace full independence

properties.name: Second Continental Congress
properties.role: Governing body of the United Colonies/States
properties.intentions: Represent colonies, coordinate war effort, establish self-governance

properties.name: British Parliament
properties.role: Lawmaking authority for the British Empire

properties.name: Stamp Act Congress
properties.intentions: Seek united action against Stamp Act

properties.name: Sons of Liberty
properties.intentions: Make British tax laws unenforceable, resist British authority

properties.name: Thomas Hutchinson
properties.beliefs: Colonists could not enjoy all English liberties

properties.name: John Dickinson
properties.beliefs: Argued against constitutionality of taxes for revenue

properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.intentions: Agitate for independence, create Committees of Correspondence, lead Boston Tea Party

properties.name: Committees of Correspondence
properties.intentions: Coordinate resistance, provide framework for rebel government

properties.name: France
properties.role: Foreign power, supporter of colonial cause

properties.source_text_quote: its 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
Parliament agreed and repealed the tax on February 21, 1766
The repeal nonetheless caused widespread celebrations in the colonies.

in his widely read pamphlet, Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania, John Dickinson argued against the constitutionality of the acts because their purpose was to raise revenue and not to regulate trade.
In Boston, Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence, which linked Patriots in all 13 colonies and eventually provided the framework for a rebel government.
On December 16, 1773, ... they boarded and dumped chests of tea owned by the British East India Company into Boston Harbor.
The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts, further darkening colonial opinion towards England.
The revolution culminated in the American Revolutionary War, which was launched on April 19, 1775, in the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
But in 1781, a decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown inspired King George III and the British to negotiate an end to colonial rule
